RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - MICHELSON WATER RECLAMATION PLANT

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Irvine Ranch Water District (IRWD) has established a risk management plan according to EPA's regulations (40 CFR Part 68) to enhance already existing safety and emergency response programs.  IRWD is extremely cautious in the handling of all chemicals and is very diligent about safety for its employees and its communities. IRWD staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor its facilities to provide safeguards, while effectively employing these useful chemicals. These chemicals play an important role in water treatment and water reclamation, enabling everyone to lead healthier lives.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Irvine Ranch Water District (IRWD) has an emergency response plan in effect to handle potential emergency situations at this facility. This plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

Key elements of the Emergency Response Plan include:

 - A detailed Emergency Response Action Guide
 - Key phone numbers and contact points for the IRWD Emergency Response Team
 - Incident Command System (ICS) w/Unified Command interface
 - ICS position descriptions w/responsibilities
 - Vicinity and evacuation maps
 - Detailed task-by-task plans for:
     - Evacuation
     - Fire in a Process or Non-Process Area
     - Injuries
     - Threats/Civil Disorder
     - Wild land or Adjacent Property Fire
     - External Events (e.g., seismic)
     - Potential Imminent Danger to Personnel
     - Chemical Spill (e.g., caustic, aqueous ammonia)
     - Chlorine Release
     - Off-Site Event Involving a Hazardous Material

The scrubber system is tied to a dedicated power source which is automatically switched to an emergency diesel generator in case of electric power loss to the plant.


Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

IRWD has a Process Safety Management program in place to manage the handling of chlorine.  The program includes strict requirements for written operating procedures, personnel training, contractor safety, equipment maintenance, incident investigation, process hazard analysis, management of change and periodic review or audit of program elements.  Management of change element addresses proper implementation of system updates to ensure that all changes are reviewed properly by knowledgeable persons, all engineering documents and operating procedures reflect the change, and personnel are trained on the change.   Process Safety Management also requires a pre-startup safety review to ensure that the system is properly reviewed before it is put back into service after a major change.  

In addition to Process Safety Management, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are strictly followed.  Also, common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute are implemented in system design and day-to-day system operation.  


Five Year Accident History

The five-year accident history (November 1998 to November 2003) for the Michelson WRP reveals that there were no reportable accidents during this period.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

IRWD is taking additional steps to further public safety. The Emergency Response Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated to ensure it is maintained current.  This Plan has been reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

Chlorine is used at Irvine Ranch Water District Michelson Water Reclamation Plant for disinfecting the wastewater treated by the plant.  The main elements of the chlorination system are located in a dedicated building.  The system employs many safety features.  Almost the entire system is operated under vacuum.  In case of a break, the vacuum regulator closes automatically minimizing the quantity of chlorine gas that may escape from the system.  Also, the entire system is connected to the gaseous side of the storage container.  This is also an important safety feature.  Aside from container side wall failure (an extremely unlikely event), there is no possibility of liquid release from the chlorination system.  The system is also equipped with shutoff mechanisms that close the main valves in case of an emergency.  To minimize the impact of a seismic event, in addition to robust seismic design of the structures and system components, a seismic vibration detector is installed in the building that shuts off all the main valves of the system.  

Chlorine detectors (5 total) are installed at key locations.  The detectors alarm locally and remotely (i.e., notify the duty operator of the plant.)  Also, the signal from the detectors is used to activate the scrubber system.
